summaries.body: Japan defeated England, 2-1, in the Women's World Cup semifinals and will play the U.S. for the title on Sunday.
European police said they would create a new unit aimed at discovering and dismantling social media accounts that Islamist radicals use for recruitment and propaganda.
Prince removed his music from all streaming services except for Tidal. There has not yet been an explanation.
A Saudi prince vowed to give away his entire $32 billion fortune to charitable causes in Saudi Arabia and elsewhere. He gave no time frame.

display_asset.caption: President Obama picked up Kelly Bryant, who had written him a letter about how the health law had improved her life, from her home in Nashville on Wednesday.  He later spoke at an event promoting the law.

summaries.body: President Obama, above with a woman who had written to him, flew into mostly Republican territory on Wednesday to push for expanding health care to more poor people.
The Muslim Brotherhood called for a rebellion against President Abdel Fattah el-Sissi, saying its leaders were killed in a Cairo apartment on Wednesday.

display_asset.caption: Ben Burley of Breaking Benjamin in 2008.

summaries.body: Breaking Benjamin's "Dark Before Dawn" debuted atop the Billboard album chart this week. It is the rock band's first No. 1 album.
Kevin Love, one of the top free agents available in the N.B.A., signed again with the Cleveland Cavaliers, saying he has "unfinished business."
Automakers rode the wave of surging sales for yet another month in June, with sales up nearly across the board. But one company was left out: General Motors.
Silent for 33 years, Wolf volcano in the Galápagos Islands released an explosive howl a few weeks ago, spewing fire and ash nearly 50,000 feet high. NASA released images.
Liberian officials confirmed a second Ebola case in the town where the virus was recently detected on a teenager's corpse, seven weeks after Liberia was declared Ebola-free.
The U.N. declared its highest-level humanitarian emergency in Yemen, where over 80 percent of the population needs aid. Officials said the country is one step away from famine.
Macy’s, the department store chain, is ending its relationship with Donald J. Trump and phasing out his line of clothing after his remarks about Mexican immigrants.
President Obama, calling it a "historic step," said the United States and Cuba had agreed to reopen embassies in each other’s capitals.
Heavy rainfall over the past three days triggered devastating mudslides in Darjeeling, India, that left at least 30 dead and many others missing.
The U.S. private sector ramped up hiring in June, adding 237,000 jobs, the largest number in six months.
A woman fought off bees, survived on apples and started a wildfire to summon help after giving birth in a lonely stretch of Northern California forest, she told local television.
Britain is experiencing its hottest day in nine years, with temperatures of up to 93 degrees in some areas.
Today is "pay day" for Bobby Bonilla, the baseball player whose career ended in 2001. The Mets must pay him about $1.2 million every year until his contract expires in 2035.
The World Food Program said it had to reduce food aid for Syrian refugees in Lebanon because of a funding crisis and may have to halt food support for most refugees in Jordan.

display_asset.credit: Clarendon County Fire Department, via Reuters

summaries.body: Another predominantly African-American church has burned in the South, the latest in a string of fires that has put congregations on edge.

posts.footer: The Associated Press | The New York Times

summaries.body: Toyota said Julie Hamp, the highest-ranking female executive in its history, had resigned. She was arrested in Japan last month on suspicion of importing a banned painkiller.
A woman turned up in a town in California, with a diagnosis of cancer, suffering from amnesia and speaking some words with an Australian accent.
A long-awaited report from the Airports Commission recommends building a third runway at Heathrow, rather than a second at Gatwick, to serve London.

posts.footer: Jon Bon Jovi, who, a day after hosting a Hillary Rodham Clinton fundraiser, let Chris Christie use his song “Who Says You Can’t Go Home” for his presidential campaign announcement, via Politico

summaries.body: My friendships are apolitical, and yes, I absolutely gave him permission to use my songs.
A record 137,000 people crossed the Mediterranean Sea in the first half of this year trying to reach the shores of Europe, the United Nations said.

posts.footer: The South China Morning Post | The New York Times

summaries.body: China's rubber-stamp legislature passed a far-reaching national security law that analysts said would strengthen the Communist Party's hold on power.
Uber criticized a proposal to put a freeze on for-hire vehicle licenses in New York City while a traffic-congestion study is conducted, calling it an attempt to limit competition.
A closely watched survey found Japanese businesses in an upbeat mood, which analysts said should ease pressure on the central bank to expand monetary stimulus.
Aid officials may add Yemen to a list of the world’s most severe humanitarian crises, putting pressure on the Saudi-led military coalition there. Above, Sana, the capital.
The F.B.I. is investigating several physical attacks on high-capacity Internet cables in the San Francisco Bay Area over the past year, including one on Tuesday.
Dirty drinking water and open defecation, particularly in rural areas of many developing countries, are threatening gains in child survival rates, two major U.N. agencies said.
The contractor who built the balcony that collapsed in Berkeley, Calif., killing six people, filed a restraining order against the county's district attorney to preserve evidence.

display_asset.caption: The centipede was named after Hades, the Greek god of the underworld.

summaries.body: The world’s deepest-dwelling centipede was discovered living as much as 3,600 feet below the surface in Croatia. It was named after Hades, the Greek god of the underworld.
Drug and medical device companies paid nearly $6.5 billion to U.S. doctors and research hospitals in 2014 for things like speaking engagements about their products.

display_asset.caption: Christine McCarthy has been promoted to chief financial officer at Disney. She previously served as the company's treasurer.

summaries.body: Disney named Christine M. McCarthy as its first female chief financial officer, adding another female executive to the company's predominantly male senior ranks.
The chief watchdog of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Richard Griffin, said he would retire. The move came a day after a group of whistle-blowers called for his removal.
You may have noticed what appear to be two superbright stars near the horizon recently, but they're not stars; they're Venus and Jupiter, and we can help you best see them.
Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, tried to answer questions on his Facebook page, but the social network had trouble handling the load.
A crowdfunding campaign called “Greek Bailout Fund” is trying to raise money to help Greece repay its creditors. It has a long way to go to meet its goal of 1.6 billion euros.
Phil Knight, a co-founder of Nike, announced plans to step away from the company and recommended its chief executive replace him as chairman.

posts.footer: The Times's fashion critic, via Twitter

summaries.body: Donna Karan is stepping down as designer of Donna Karan, and the main line is suspended. An era in American fashion is over.
The man who killed 38 people at a hotel in Tunisia last week spent time in a militant camp in Libya, overlapping with two men who killed 22 at a museum in March, officials said.
The Oklahoma Supreme Court ruled that a monument of the Ten Commandments on the state Capitol grounds violates the state's Constitution and must be removed.
A former leader of a notorious Mexican drug cartel has been sentenced to 30 years in a U.S. prison and fined $100 million on drug and money laundering convictions.
A lawsuit filed by drivers who got stuck in traffic during the lane closure scandal in New Jersey was dismissed by a federal judge, but could be amended and refiled.
The A.C.L.U. in Louisiana is suing Gov. Bobby Jindal, who is running for president, over an executive order he said would protect people who oppose same-sex marriage.
A federal appeals court upheld a ruling that determined Apple to be the leader of an industrywide conspiracy among book publishers to raise prices of digital books.
The State Department will release 3,000 pages of emails from Hillary Rodham Clinton at 9 p.m. Eastern Tuesday, just before a court deadline to do so by the end of the month.

posts.footer: Senator Ted Cruz, defending Donald J. Trump's inflammatory comments about Mexican immigrants, via The New York Times

summaries.body: I like Donald Trump. I think he’s terrific, I think he’s brash, I think he speaks the truth.
A statue of Ben Tillman, a former South Carolina governor widely known as a white supremacist, was vandalized with red paint on the grounds of the State House.
No. 3 Simona Halep and No. 12 Eugenie Bouchard both lost in the first round at Wimbledon to opponents ranked outside the top 100.

display_asset.caption: Lester Holt on the set of "NBC Nightly News." NBC has been promoting Mr. Holt as the face of its evening news broadcast.

summaries.body: In Lester Holt's first week as the official anchor of NBC's "Nightly News," the show drew its biggest audience since April with 8 million viewers.
Gov. Jerry Brown of California signed a bill that requires mandatory vaccinations for nearly all children in schools. "The science is clear," he said in a statement.
Apple Music, a streaming service, debuts today as competition to Spotify, Rdio, Google Play Music and Tidal. Here are some of the key differences.
President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt said he would change the law to allow faster executions in the aftermath of the assassination of the country's lead prosecutor.
Eurostar and Eurotunnel train services were suspended after striking ferry workers set fire to the track in Calais, France. Ferries were halted as workers blockaded a port.
To balance out a very gradual slowing of the Earth’s rotation, scientists are adding an extra second to the day on Tuesday. There’s a debate over whether it is worthwhile.
Serena and Venus Williams have pulled out of women's doubles at Wimbledon for unknown reasons. Both of the sisters won first-round singles matches on Monday.
The Vatican released the schedule for Pope Francis' visit to the U.S. in September. His three days in New York include a service at the 9/11 Memorial Museum.
For the first time in more than two years, 50 percent of Americans approve of the way President Obama is handling the presidency, a poll shows.
BREAKING: Greek Finance Minister Varoufakis confirms Greece will not pay IMF debt due Tuesday.
Chinese stock markets staged a powerful rally, sending share prices sharply higher in a volatile day of trading. The surge came after some of the sharpest losses in years.
European officials agreed on Tuesday to outlaw cellphone roaming charges, beginning in 2017, when people travel across the 28-member bloc.
Four Britons who were wounded in a terrorist attack at a Tunisian beach last week were flown home on a military plane. They will need additional medical treatment.
Three American churches this week are considering resolutions to divest from companies deemed supportive of Israeli occupation in the Palestinian territories.
Staff members were evacuated from a prison near Melbourne, Australia, where news footage showed inmates with their faces covered, carrying sticks and beating doors.

posts.footer: Agence France-Presse's deputy bureau chief in Tokyo, on reports of a fire on the bullet train from the Japanese capital to Osaka, via Twitter

summaries.body: "We have been informed that a passenger in a car on the train covered him or herself with oil and set it on fire," JR spox tells @AFP
The body of a 17-year-old who died last week in Liberia tested positive for Ebola, an official said, seven weeks after the country was declared free of the virus.
South Korea said it had gone three days without a new MERS case, though an 81-year-old woman became the 33rd person to die from the outbreak.
The United Nations is reducing its humanitarian aid staff in parts of Asia, saying that Indonesia and other countries have improved their disaster-relief capacities.

display_asset.caption: Scholars say the Great Wall of China is disappearing as a result of erosion, theft of bricks and damage from tourists scrambling over unrestored sections.

summaries.body: Much of the Great Wall of China has been lost to erosion, tourist damage and villagers' stealing bricks, according to reports in the country's state-run news media.
The Colorado Supreme Court struck down a voucher program that allowed parents to use taxpayer dollars to send their children to private schools.

posts.footer: The Associated Press, via Hawaii News Now

summaries.body: Gov. David Ige of Hawaii said he would veto a bill banning sex trafficking and would ask for a new proposal. The state is the only one without a comprehensive law on the subject.
AC/DC songs will be added to streaming music services as early as Tuesday, sources said. The band has long been one of the biggest holdouts in the digital music market.
Research released Monday suggests Google sometimes alters search results to play up its own content despite people's preferences.
After criticism by advocates, immigration authorities will consider housing transgender detainees based on the gender they identify with, officials said.

display_asset.caption: Edith Macefield refused to sell her home to developers almost a decade ago. Now, the house could be torn down after the new buyers backed out on the sale because of the high cost of bringing it up to modern building code requirements.
display_asset.credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times

summaries.body: A house in Seattle that's popular with locals and tourists for its resemblance to the home in the Disney movie "Up" could be demolished after a recent sale fell through.
Dwyane Wade, the Miami Heat All-Star, will become a free agent after deciding not to pick up his option for next season. He was scheduled to make $16.1 million.
Discovery Communications won the exclusive rights to broadcast the Olympics from 2018 to 2024 for most of Europe, the media company announced.
The South Carolina Legislature appears to have enough votes to remove the Confederate flag from the Statehouse grounds, according to a newspaper survey.
Poisonings from a toxin carried by barracuda and other sport fish have been seriously underestimated in Florida, according to a study.
More than 26 million people overlaid a rainbow flag over their Facebook profile photos after Friday's Supreme Court decision on same-sex marriage, Facebook said.
Two fugitives appeared to have sprinkled pepper in their tracks to throw search dogs off their scent, as has been seen in movies. But did it work? Not likely, an expert said.
Bo Ryan, the men's basketball coach of the Wisconsin Badgers, said he would retire after next season. He has led the team to two straight Final Four appearances.
The California Legislature passed a bill that would require mandatory vaccinations for nearly all children in schools. The bill now goes to the governor.

display_asset.caption: Khader Adnan during a protest in the West Bank village of Araba in 2012. Mr. Adnan ended a 55-day fast on Monday after Israeli officials, concerned he could die, agreed to release him.

summaries.body: A Palestinian prisoner, above, who became a symbol of resistance to Israel’s occupation ended a 55-day fast after Israeli officials, concerned he could die, released him.
The L.A. County district attorney will unveil Monday a unit dedicated to reviewing the integrity of convictions for serious or violent crimes, joining a growing national trend.
France seemed to back away from getting the United Nations Security Council involved in the gnarled and stuck peace talks between Israel and Palestinians.

posts.footer: BBC via YouTube | The New York Times | The Guardian

asset.embed_html: <iframe class="embedly-embed" src="//cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fembed%2F2XPO8B2QZ1g%3Ffeature%3Doembed%26start%3D214%26start%3D214&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Ft%3D214%26v%3D2XPO8B2QZ1g&image=https%3A%2F%2Fi.ytimg.com%2Fvi%2F2XPO8B2QZ1g%2Fhqdefault.jpg&key=170aca4a25074a88942b11f27e7ca43f&type=text%2Fhtml&schema=youtube" width="854" height="480" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

summaries.body: Glastonbury, the huge summer music festival, sang Happy Birthday on Sunday to the Dalai Lama, above with Patti Smith. The Guardian provided blanket coverage.
Rukmini Callimachi answered questions about her story of an American woman and a British man that may provide clues about how ISIS recruits new members.
California's legislature is expected to pass a bill on Monday moving to end exemptions from state immunization laws based on religious or other personal beliefs.
Protesters in Parwan in northern Afghanistan blocked the main highway there after U.S. forces raided the village of a local strongman and blew up his weapons depot.

display_asset.caption: A screenshot of a photo illustration used by the Democratic National Committee in a post on Medium.

summaries.body: Democrats are welcoming Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey to the presidential race with a post on Medium. But they may have more than one target.
Authorities in France took two managers for Uber into custody for questioning over suspected illicit activity involving its ride-hailing service, a spokeswoman said.
The director of a school in India was beaten to death by a mob after the staff was accused of killing two students, officials said. Autopsies later showed the boys had drowned.
Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain promised a “full spectrum” response to the assault that is feared to have killed at least 30 British tourists in Tunisia.
A woman severely burned in a weekend explosion at a water park in Taiwan died on Monday, the first fatality from the blast. More than 200 people are still in intensive care.
Graves in the Muslim section of a cemetery in Nottingham, England, were damaged in what is being investigated as a hate crime following the terrorist attack in Tunisia.

display_asset.caption: The student leader Joshua Wong at a Hong Kong hospital early Monday.

summaries.body: Joshua Wong, the 18-year-old student who led months of protests for a free election of Hong Kong’s leader, said he was assaulted by an unidentified man on a street.
